title-group.article-title: Evidence of Long Memory in the Indian Stock Market

abstract.p: This article tests the small sample properties of three approaches in estimating the long-range dependence measure (the R/S approach, the R/S-AL approach and the Detrending Moving Average (DMA) approach) using Monte Carlo simulation experiments. We use simulated series of Gaussian noise and fractional Gaussian noise of varying lengths (252, 504, 1008, 2016 and 4032) which approximately represents daily data series of 1 year, 2 years, 4 years, 8 years and 16 years period. We observe a pronounced reduction in the variance and the mean absolute error under the DMA approach when the sample size increases, which indicates that the DMA approach performs better than the R/S and the R/S-AL approaches. In addition, we test for the presence of long memory in daily data from the Indian stock market. In particular, we examine the dynamic nature of market efficiency in the Indian stock market by using a moving sub-sample window of 1,008 observations (approximately 4 years of daily data). Our findings support the presence of long-range dependence in the Indian stock market. Furthermore, S&P CNX Nifty shows a highly dynamic behaviour in its efficiency characteristics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The presence of long memory in the stock market supports the notion of market inefficiency. Market inefficiency refers to the fact that the market does not react immediately as new information flows in but responds to it gradually over a period of time. The presence of long memory in the evolution of asset prices describes the higher-order correlation structure in a series and supports the possibility of predicting its behaviour. The analysis of long memory in asset prices is important for practitioners because its presence can have a significant impact on risk management, portfolio selection and trading strategies. Modelling the Hurst exponent is a popular way of detecting long-range dependence in a time series process. The Hurst exponent is a dimensionless parameter and diverse methodologies exist to estimate it. The Hurst exponent lies in the range 0 ≤ H ≤ 1.

The study of long-range dependence in financial time series has a long history and has remained an active topic of research in economics and finance. (See for instance Cutland et al., 1995; Greene & Fielitz, 1977; Mandelbrot, 1971). Greene and Fielitz (1977) utilize the Hurst rescaled-range (R/S) method and provide evidence in support of long memory in the daily stock return series. Lo (1991) finds that the classical R/S test used by Mandelbrot and Green and Fielitz suffers from the drawback that it is unable to distinguish between long-term memory and short-term dependence. Lo (1991) proposes a modified test of the R/S statistic which can distinguish between short-term dependence and long-term memory and finds that daily stock returns do not show long-range dependence properties. Peters (1991) use the R/S approach to study the long memory characteristics in daily exchange rates data of US dollars, Japanese yen, British pounds, Euros and Singapore dollars and finds evidence in support of long memory in exchange rates. Willinger et al. (1999) empirically find that Lo’s modified R/S test leading to the acceptance of the null hypothesis of no long-range dependence for CSRP (Center for Research in Security Prices) data is less conclusive than it appears. This is so because of the conservative nature of the test statistic in rejecting the null hypothesis of no long-range dependence, by attributing what is found in the data to short-term dependence instead. Nath (2001) uses the R/S analysis to test for long memory for all time lags and finds evidence of long memory in the Indian stock market. Corazza and Malliaris (2002) find that the Hurst exponent does not remain fixed but changes dynamically over time. They also provide evidence that foreign currency returns follow either a fractional Brownian motion or a Pareto-Levy stable distribution. Razdan (2002) finds mono-fractal behaviour in the BSE SENSEX time series which is characterised by a fractional Brownian motion. Cajueiro and Tabak (2004) use the rolling sample approach to calculate Hurst exponents over the sample period October 1992 to October 1996 and provide evidence of long-range dependence in Asian markets.

The contribution of this study is twofold. First, we evaluate the small sample properties of the three long memory estimation approaches which comprise the R/S analysis, the R/S-AL analysis and the Detrending Moving Average (DMA) analysis and compare their performance using Monte Carlo simulations. We use the Gaussian white noise and the fractional Gaussian noise simulated series to achieve our first goal. Second, we study the evolution of market efficiency in the Indian stock market using a rolling sub-sample approach to estimate Hurst exponents over time, as in Cajueiro and Tabak (2004). To our knowledge, the estimation of the Hurst exponent using a rolling sub-sample approach has not been implemented previously in the Indian context. In particular, we would like to note that the time varying Hurst exponent approach is very important to understand the dynamic nature of the evolution of market efficiency.

The remainder of this article is organised as follows: The second section introduces the tests we will use in this study. The third section discusses the Monte Carlo simulations to examine their small sample properties. The fourth section describes the data used in this study and discusses the computational details. The fifth section reports the empirical results and the sixth section concludes with a summary of our main findings.

sec.title: The Martingale Hypothesis
sec.p:
According to the martingale model, tomorrow’s price is expected to be the same as today’s price. Suppose xt is the natural logarithm of a stock price and so, for xt to follow a martingale,
(1) Et (xt/t–1) = xt–1

where t–1 be the information set consist of information upto time t – 1 which includes xt–1 as well. In other words, the martingale model implies that xt – xt–1 is a fair game, that is,
(2) Et ((xt – xt–1)/t–1) = 0
This shows why fair games are sometimes called martingale difference sequences.

The martingale model can also be written as:
(3) xt = xt–1 + εt

where εt is the martingale difference. It looks similar to the random walk model. However, the martingale model is a less restrictive form of the random walk model. The random walk model requires its increments to be IID (identically and independently distributed), but the martingale model only requires the increment to be mean-independent, thus allowing for general forms of heteroskedasticity. Mandelbrot (1963) and Fama (1965a; 1965b) find that the martingale difference model is consistent with stock price changes which may show dependence in higher conditional moments.

sec.title: R/S Analysis
sec.p: Mandelbrot and Wallis (1969) propose the R/S analysis based on Hurst (1951), which helps in the estimation of the self-similarity parameter and the long-range dependence parameter H in the time series. The procedure for using the R/S analysis is as follows:

First divide the time series (of returns) of length L into d subseries (Zi,m) of length n. For each subseries m = 1, ….., d:
Find the mean (Em) and the standard deviation (Sm).
Next, normalise the data of subseries (Zi,m) by subtracting the sample mean, Yi,m = Zi,m - Em for I = 1, … . …, n.
Find a cumulative time series for i = 1, ……., n.
Find the range Rm = max{x1,m, ………, xn,m} - min{x1,m, ………, xn,m}.
Rescale the range (Rm/Sm).
Calculate the mean value of the rescaled range for all sub-series of length n
(R/S)n=1d∑m=1d (RmSm)

R/S statistics asymptotically follows the relation:
(R/S)n ~ cnH
The value of the Hurst exponent H can be estimated by running an ordinary least squares (OLS) linear regression over a sample of increasing time horizons.
sec.disp-formula: (4) log (R/S)n = log c + H log n
sec.p: Note that H = 0.5 for white noise. When the process is persistent (i.e., has long memory), then H > 0.5 and for an anti-persistent process (i.e., with mean reversion), H < 0.5.

sec.title: Modified R/S Analysis (R/S-AL)
sec.p: In small samples, the R/S analysis can show a significant deviation of the estimates of the Hurst exponent from 0.5 even for the Gaussian white noise. To overcome this problem, Anis and Lloyd (1976) and Peters (1994) introduce a new formulation to improve the performance of R/S analysis for small n.
The Hurst exponent is calculated as 0.5 plus the slope of (R/S)n – E(R/S)n. The resulting statistics is known as R/S-AL.

sec.title: Detrending Moving Average Analysis (DMA)
sec.p:
In order to calculate the Hurst exponent, the detrending moving average (DMA) approach is used. Suppose xt is a financial time series with t = 1,……….., N. The nth order moving average of xt is given by:
x̄n, t=1n∑i = 0n − 1xt−1

In finding x̄n, t, the last point of the time window of size n is taken as the reference point. The series xt is detrended by subtracting x̄n, t, and the standard deviation of xt about the moving average x̄n, t, is computed as follows:
(6)
σDMA=1N−n∑i = nN[xi−x̄n, i]2

σDMA is computed for different values of the moving average window n over the interval [n, N]. The Hurst exponent is computed as the slope of a log-log plot between σDMA and n. Arianos and Carbone (2007) show the power law behaviour:
(7)
σDMA∝nH
where H is the Hurst exponent and 0 < H< 1.

Equation (5) can also be written as:
og (σDMA) ∝ H log (n)

This linear relationship between σDMA and n on a log-log plot supports the presence of power law (fractal) scaling which indicates that there is self-similarity in the series. This means the fluctuations over small time scales are related to fluctuations over larger time scales. In particular, the Hurst exponent can be used to identify the long memory properties of the time series.

sec.title: Monte Carlo Experiment
sec.p: In this section, we undertake Monte Carlo experiments to study the small sample properties of the R/S analysis, the R/S-AL analysis and the detrending moving average (DMA) analysis. We generate samples of Gaussian white noise and fractional Gaussian noise sequences of length L = 252, 504, 1008, 2016 and 4032 approximating daily data series for 1 year, 2 years, 4 years, 8 years and 16 years, respectively. We generate 10,000 replications of simulated data for each L.

Figure 1 presents the plots of the mean value of the estimated Hurst exponent with a 95 per cent empirical confidence band for the Gaussian white noise and the fractional Gaussian noise for all the three estimation techniques. It can be observed that that R/S and R/S-AL display a large variance for all the sample sizes used in this study and a minor reduction in variance value can be detected for the R/S-AL analysis with an increase in sample size. But the DMA analysis shows a significant reduction in variance as the sample size increases from 252 to 4032. The mean value of the Hurst exponent from the R/S analysis shows a large deviation for smaller samples but as the sample size increases, the mean value of the Hurst exponent asymptotically approaches 0.5 for the Gaussian white noise and for the fractional Gaussian noise when the input Hurst exponent equals 0.5. For the R/S-AL and DMA analyses, the mean value of the Hurst exponent remains near 0.5 as the sample size increases. Overall, the DMA analysis shows desirable behaviour regarding the estimation of the Hurst exponent.

Table 1 reports the standard deviation (SD) and mean absolute error (MAE) for the R/S, R/S-AL and DMA analyses. We can see that the reduction in SD and MAE of the estimated Hurst exponent from the R/S analysis and also from the R/S-AL analysis is smaller than that for the DMA analysis for both the Gaussian white noise and the fractional Gaussian noise series.

sec.p: Figure 2 reports the power-law exponents obtained from the R/S, R/S-AL and DMA algorithms and are compared with the values when Hin = Hout for different sample sizes. The solid line represents the ideal behaviour (when Hin = Hout). For all sample sizes, the DMA power-law curves lie very near to the ideal curve. Both R/S and R/S-AL curves show deviation from the ideal behaviour which is represented by the crossover of R/S and R/S-AL curves with the ideal behaviour curves at different points for different sample sizes. As sample size increases, the R/S and R/S-AL curves gradually adjust and align with respect to the ideal curve. Thus, the DMA approach exhibits desirable properties and higher accuracy can be expected for the estimation of the long-range dependence measure.

sec.title: Data and Computational Details
sec.p: In order to test for long-range dependence in the Indian stock market, we have used daily observations of six indices of National Stock Exchange of India Ltd (NSE). The indices1 used in this study are S&P CNX Nifty (the most commonly used index, composed of 50 firms from 24 sectors), CNX100 (composed of 100 firms from 38 sectors), S&P CNX 500 (the first broad based benchmark of the Indian capital market), CNX Nifty Junior (composed of the next 50 liquid stocks after S&P CNX Nifty), Nifty Midcap 50 (to capture the movement in the midcap segment of the market), CNX Smallcap Index (which reflects the movement in small capitalised segment of the financial market) covering all the major segments of the Indian stock market. All the data are obtained from the NSE website: www.nseindia.com. The period of study for S&P CNX Nifty is from 3 May 1994 to 29 April 2011 (4214 observations); for CNX100 is from 2 Jan 2003 to 29 April 2011 (2077 observations); for S&P CNX 500 is from 8 June 1999 to 29 April 2011 (2971 observations); for CNX Nifty Junior is from 5 Oct 1995 to 29 April 2011 (3887 observations); for Nifty Midcap 50 is from 2 Jan 2001 to 29 April 2011 (2577 observations) and for CNX Smallcap Index is from 2 Jan 2004 to 29 April 2011 (1824 observations). We have used the following abbreviations for the indices in this article, that is Nifty for S&P CNX Nifty, CNX100 for CNX 100, CNX500 for S&P CNX 500, JUR for CNX Nifty Junior, MID for Nifty midcap 50, SMA for CNX Smallcap index.

Table 2 reports the descriptive statistics of the daily returns of all indices under study. The median daily return for Nifty Midcap 50 and CNX Smallcap are the highest of all the indices. The mean daily return of all the indices are almost the same except for S&P CNX Nifty which shows the lowest mean daily return. CNX Nifty junior seems to be more volatile than the other indices. All index returns show a significant negative skewness and also excess kurtosis. The Jarque-Bera and Shapiro-Wilk tests strongly reject the normality of the returns. The ARCH-LM test supports the presence of conditional heteroskedasticity in all the return series. Box-Pierce Q-test strongly rejects the presence of no significant autocorrelations in the first 20 lags for all the return series. Insignificant KPSS statistics for all the indices support the non-rejection of the null hypothesis of stationarity of the series. In addition, the ADF test rejects the null hypothesis of a unit root in all the index return series.

It can clearly be observed that all the indices display a great deal of momentum in their returns and prices series which includes a steep rise in the index value from 2005 to the beginning of 2008 and a sudden drop from the beginning of 2008 to the end of 2008 and again a sudden rise in index value from 2009 onwards. We also observe volatility clustering during the period 2007–2009 for all the indices.

sec.title: Empirical Results
sec.p: Table 3 reports the results of the estimated values of the Hurst exponent using the R/S-AL and the Detrending Moving Average (DMA) approaches along with their standard errors for all the indices used in the study. We have divided the whole sample into two subsamples to study the impact of the sub-prime mortgage crisis on the Indian stock market. Subsample I consists of data before 9 January 2008 and subsample II has data from 10 December 2008 to 29 April 2011. The period from 10 January 2008 to 9 December 2008 is the period of extreme volatility and the indices experience steep fall in their index values.

For whole sample, the Hurst exponent for S&P CNX Nifty and S&P CNX 500 are closer to 0.5 compared to what it is for all the other indices, which indicates that S&P CNX Nifty and S&P CNX 500 are more efficient than the other indices of the Indian stock market. The Hurst exponent estimated under the DMA approach varies from 0.539 to 0.652 for the whole sample, with it being 0.539 for S&P CNX Nifty and 0.652 for CNX Smallcap. This provides evidence that S&P CNX Nifty is the most efficient and CNX Smallcap is the least efficient of all the indices considered in this study. On the other hand, the Hurst exponent estimated for the whole sample under the R/S-AL approach varies from 0.526 to 0.583, with it being 0.526 for S&P CNX Nifty and 0.583 for CNX Midcap. This indicates that S&P CNX Nifty is the most efficient index under study, thus confirming what was found under the DMA approach, and also suggests that CNX Midcap is the least efficient.

Before the sub-prime crisis, CNX 100 appears to be the least efficient and S&P CNX Nifty maintains its earlier position as being the most efficient when the Hurst exponent was estimated using the DMA approach using the whole sample. It is worth noting here that the R/S-AL approach provides similar results. After the sub-prime crisis, CNX Nifty Junior displays strong evidence of inefficiency in its behaviour when compared to the other indices.

Figure 5 reports the scaling of log(σDMA) from the detrending moving average (DMA) analysis for all the indices under study. Notice that log(σDMA) increases concavely for smaller values of log(n) and scales linearly for higher values of log(n) for all the indices. This type of behaviour indicates that the estimates of the Hurst exponent are affected by the presence of short-range dependence in the return series. It may also be noted that the slope of the best fit line of these scaling plots gives the value of Hurst exponent.

sec.p: Figure 6 presents the plots of the Hurst exponent estimated under the DMA approach using a rolling window sub-sample approach. In all these plots, the y-axis represents the estimated Hurst exponent and the x-axis represents calendar time. A rolling window of 1008 observations (approximately 4 years of data) is used to calculate the Hurst exponent. The results obtained by the rolling window approach are attributed to the data of the leftover period. The Hurst exponent estimated using the moving subsample approach for S&P CNX Nifty shows wide variation in its behaviour between mean reversion and long memory over the period of study. Before the year 2004, S&P CNX Nifty exhibits signs of mean reversion for the most part. But after 2004 and before the sub-prime crisis, it shows strong evidence in support of long-range dependence behaviour. During the period of sub-prime crisis, the index displays random behaviour. But after the sub-prime crisis, we once again find some evidence in support of long-range dependence in the series. CNX 100 and S&P CNX 500 also show similar behaviour in the index values during and after sub-prime crisis. In addition, we find signs of mean reversion in S&P CNX 500 for a very small period during the year 2003. CNX Nifty Junior, CNX Midcap and CNX Smallcap show highly inefficient characteristics over time. Like the S&P CNX Nifty, CNX Nifty Junior shows some signs of random walk behaviour during the period of the sub-prime crisis and at the start of the dot-com bubble.

sec.p: For all the other periods, we find strong evidence in support of long memory behaviour of the index values. In case of CNX Midcap and CNX Smallcap, we do not find evidence of mean reversion, although there is evidence of random walk behaviour around the period of the sub-prime crisis, but for most of the sample periods, the stock prices exhibit long memory behaviour.

Table 4 reports the descriptive statistics of the time varying Hurst exponent. The mean and median values of the Hurst exponent support the finding that S&P CNX Nifty is more efficient compared to the other indices under study. Except for S&P CNX Nifty, the Hurst exponents for all the other indices show significant negative skewness. The Jarque-Bera statistic supports the rejection of the null hypothesis of normality of the Hurst exponent series over time for all the indices at conventional levels of significance. A higher value of the standard deviation of the Hurst exponent for S&P CNX Nifty indicates a high volatility in the changing behaviour of the index in comparison to the other indices. Significant ARCH-LM supports the presence of conditional heteroskedasticity in the Hurst exponents for all the indices.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article tests the small sample properties of the R/S analysis, the R/S-AL analysis and the DMA analysis and makes the case that the DMA approach is a good method for estimating the Hurst exponent. We also examine the evolution of long-range dependence in the Indian stock market over time using six indices, namely S&P CNX Nifty, CNX 100, S&P CNX 500, CNX Nifty Junior, Nifty Midcap 50 and CNX Smallcap which cover the major part of the Indian market. We apply the DMA approach to all these indices which confirms the scaling behaviour in the Indian stock market. In addition, our analysis regarding the scaling behaviour supports the fact that estimates of the Hurst exponent are affected by the presence of short-range dependence in the index return series. The analysis of the evolution of Hurst exponents regarding long memory in the pre and post-sub-prime crisis periods show the occurrence of abrupt changes in long-range dependence measure around the sub-prime crisis. We also find some sign of anti-persistence (mean reversion) in the returns of S&P CNX Nifty and S&P CNX 500 (Hurst exponent being less than 0.5 for some periods).

The possible implications of the empirical findings are: (a) the DMA approach can be applied to develop strategies in the different scales in financial engineering and portfolio management, (b) the relative transaction cost is greater for trading strategies related to short horizon predictability than the strategies related to long horizon predictability. Hence the long investment horizon strategy can results in an unexploited profit opportunity. This article focuses on exploring the dynamic nature of the market efficiency in the Indian stock market and does not identify the possible sources that impact market efficiency. Hence, further research can be undertaken to identify the possible sources of the long-range dependence in the returns of the Indian stock market.
